title: Erdős Problem #84: Counting Cycle Sets
description: How many distinct 'cycle sets' can graphs on n vertices have? The count f(n) lies between 2^{n/2} and 2^{n-2}. Verstraëte proved f(n) = o(2^n), but the second part showing f(n)/2^{n/2} → ∞ remains open.

overview.historicalContext:
This problem concerns the 'cycle set' of a graph - the set of lengths of cycles that occur. Erdős and Faudree asked how many distinct cycle sets are achievable for graphs on n vertices. They established bounds 2^{n/2} < f(n) ≤ 2^{n-2}.

Verstraëte (2004) solved Part 1 by showing f(n) = o(2^n), with the bound f(n) ≪ 2^{n - n^{1/10}}. This proves that not all subsets of {3,...,n} can be cycle sets. Nenadov (2025) dramatically improved this to f(n) ≪ 2^{n - n^{1/2-o(1)}}.

Part 2 - whether f(n)/2^{n/2} → ∞ - remains open, as does the question of whether lim f(n)^{1/n} exists.
overview.problemStatement:
**Problem Statement (PARTIALLY SOLVED)**

The cycle set of a graph G on n vertices is A ⊆ {3,...,n} where ℓ ∈ A iff G contains a cycle of length ℓ. Let f(n) count the number of achievable cycle sets.

**Part 1:** Prove f(n) = o(2^n)
**Status:** SOLVED (Verstraëte 2004)

**Part 2:** Prove f(n)/2^{n/2} → ∞
**Status:** OPEN

**Known Bounds:**
- Lower: f(n) > 2^{n/2} (Erdős-Faudree)
- Upper: f(n) ≪ 2^{n - n^{1/2-o(1)}} (Nenadov 2025)
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines cycle sets and the counting function f(n). Verstraëte's theorem is axiomatized for Part 1, along with Nenadov's improved bound. We formalize both parts of the problem statement, marking Part 2 as open. The key insight - that structural constraints limit achievable cycle sets - is captured through the structural_constraint axiom.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #84 is PARTIALLY SOLVED. Part 1 (f(n) = o(2^n)) was solved by Verstraëte (2004), with Nenadov (2025) giving the best known bound f(n) ≪ 2^{n - n^{1/2-o(1)}}. Part 2 (f(n)/2^{n/2} → ∞) remains OPEN.
conclusion.implications: This problem reveals deep structure in graph theory: not all subsets of {3,...,n} can be the set of cycle lengths of a graph. The progression of upper bounds shows active research. Understanding achievable cycle sets connects to extremal graph theory and structural graph theory.
openQuestions: Does lim f(n)^{1/n} exist? If so, what is its value?
Can the Nenadov upper bound be further improved?
